#TOOLTIP: the macro-features of the Ocean that everyone should know about
the lenses from which Ocean activities can be understood
the different ways of nurturing Ocean Literacy
The Ocean is one big, interconnected system with diverse features.
The Ocean shapes Earth's landscapes and ecosystems over time.
The Ocean regulates climate and weather on a global scale.
The Ocean makes life on Earth possible by providing essential conditions.
The Ocean supports a vast variety of ecosystems and life forms.
The Ocean and humans are deeply linked in multiple ways.
The Ocean remains mostly unexplored, holding many mysteries.
Looking at the Ocean through scientific methods to understand its processes.
Considering historical perspectives on human-ocean interactions.
Examining oceanic features and issues through a geographic lens.
Seeing how gender influences access to and use of ocean resources.
Understanding different values and perspectives in ocean-related decisions.
Exploring cultural traditions and knowledge tied to the Ocean.
Framing ocean sustainability in terms of environmental, economic, and social factors.
Knowing about ocean-related topics and their interconnections.
Communicating ocean knowledge with peers and communities.
Engaging in behaviors and decisions that impact ocean sustainability.
Developing attitudes and concerns regarding ocean-related issues.
Being aware of ocean-related challenges and their significance.
Participating in activism and advocacy for ocean conservation.
Experiencing emotional connections to the Ocean and its changes.
Engaging with the Ocean physically or virtually to build connections.
Adapting to ocean changes and challenges with resilience.
Trusting and evaluating transparency in ocean-related information.
